newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cr Lyonnais plan to go to EU soon - paper.
newsitem.headline: Cr Lyonnais plan to go to EU soon - paper.

text.p: The French government will submit a long-awaited privatisation plan for state-controlled bank Credit Lyonnais to the European Commission in the next few days, the French business daily Les Echos said.

The plan, originally due to be sent to the Commission in February, will involve the sale of virtually all the bank's European subsidiaries and will not provide for any recapitalisation of the bank, the newspaper said.
The newspaper said that capital gains from sale of certain of the bank's subsidiaries would offset capital losses from sale of other units.
Credit Lyonnais' 50 percent stake in German bank BfG would receive "special treatment", the newspaper said. Bank officials have said sale of the stake could trigger a five billion franc loss.
The centre-right government had originally been expected to recapitalise the bank to pave the way for its privatisation, expected in late 1998 or early 1999.
But Finance Minister Jean Arthuis said earlier this month that there was "no question of the state taking part in a new recapitalisation".
The bank's unexpectedly strong recovery is believed to have been a factor in the government's decision not to recapitalise the bank, banking analysts have said.
The government has bailed out Credit Lyonnais twice since the bank nearly collapsed in the early 1990s under the weight of its lending excesses. -- Paris Newsroom, +33 1 4221 5452
